results.title: Green Fingers: Looking After Lemons
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Looking After Lemons’, gardener Rod Cantrill shows ways to look after the popular lemon tree.

The narrator points out various issues that can afflict them including collar rot, leaf yellowing, leaf fall, and pests and diseases, while Cantrill works on lemon trees in a beautiful orchard. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Indoor Plants
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Indoor Plants’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to propagate and look after indoor plants.

The film contains wonderful footage of the glasshouses at Burnley Horticultural College, with plants shown including rubber plants, philodendron and rex begonias. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Pest and Disease Control
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: this is an archival film and contemporary advice should be sought when handling chemicals and poisons.

‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Pest and Disease Control’, Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to use agricultural sprays on a rose garden at Burnley Gardens.

Diseases described include black spot, aphids and powdery mildew. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: The Gods of Tiny Things
results.credit_line:
Deborah Kelly

Two-channel digital animation, colour, sound

ACMI Collection

Collage figures: Joanne Albany, Alana Ambados, Kate Andrews, Justin Ashworth, Kathryn Bird, Karen Golland, Amanda Holt, Deborah Kelly, Kath Lim, Lex Lindsay, Megan Rushton, Rie Tamaoke, Anna Tregloan
results.brief_description: Deborah Kelly’s The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopaedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies.

constellations_primary.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_primary.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.description:
“This work is blessed by the powers of the animator, musicians and collagists. Having such creative collaborators is the treasure of my life” – Deborah Kelly

The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life. Created at ‘collage camp’ at Bundanon on beautiful Yuin Country, this collaborative work is a poetic and urgent warning.

Deborah Kelly is a Sydney-based artist whose works have been shown around Australia, and in the Biennales of Singapore, Sydney, Thessaloniki, TarraWarra and Venice. Her projects across media are concerned with lineages of representation, politics and history in public exchange, and practices of collectivity on small and large scale, both fleeting and durational. Her newest works experiment with models of sustained creative collaboration between strangers. Kelly’s moving image artworks have been shown around the world, in galleries, cinemas and projected onto rock formations, buildings and clouds.
description_for_label:
“This work is blessed by the powers of the animator, musicians and collagists. Having such creative collaborators is the treasure of my life” – Deborah Kelly

The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life. Created at ‘collage camp’ at Bundanon on beautiful Yuin Country, this collaborative work is a poetic and urgent warning.

Deborah Kelly is a Sydney-based artist whose works have been shown around Australia, and in the Biennales of Singapore, Sydney, Thessaloniki, TarraWarra and Venice. Her projects across media are concerned with lineages of representation, politics and history in public exchange, and practices of collectivity on small and large scale, both fleeting and durational. Her newest works experiment with models of sustained creative collaboration between strangers. results.title: Mongolian Princess costume
results.credit_line:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric
results.brief_description:
From seller: A Mongolian Princess costume worn in the 1987 multi Oscar-winning drama The Last Emperor. This stunning costume was worn when the 15 year-old Pu-Yi (Wu Tao) wed’s the ‘old’ government chosen first wife and Empress, 17-year old Wan Jung.
The multi-layered costume consists of a thick white quilted gown with ties to the front, a red rayon brocade under robe overprinted in gold with panels in mulberry green and gold appliqué, high padded shoulders, tall collars, and cuffs trimmed in grey Astrakhan and Mongolian lambswool, and finally a waistcoat in maroon velvet and green brocade, overprinted in gold trimmed with antique fabric appliqués on the front and back panels. There are no sizes marked on this wonderful costume and it remains in excellent condition.
This comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.

results.title: Princess of the Blood robes
results.brief_description:
A Princess of the Blood gown and overrobe from the 1987 multi Oscar-winning historical drama The Last Emperor. These women can be seen on several occasions throughout the movie, when PuYi chooses his secondary consort, and at PuYi’s wedding to the Empress. This stunning and elaborate costume consists of a full-length gown of printed red rayon satin, overprinted with dragon robe motif, similarly printed sleeveless overrobe. Also included is a black satin headband with gold filigree buttons (some have been lost over the years) and a string of glass beads and polished stones that hang down the chest, and a cream quilted cotton under robe.
It comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.

results.title: Princess of the Blood robes costume
results.credit_line:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric
results.brief_description: This costume from The Last Emperor enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, a sense that’s reinforced by 9,500 extras who appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
results.description:
From seller: A Princess of the Blood gown and overrobe from the 1987 multi Oscar-winning historical drama The Last Emperor. These women can be seen on several occasions throughout the movie, when PuYi chooses his secondary consort, and at PuYi’s wedding to the Empress. This stunning and elaborate costume consists of a full-length gown of printed red rayon satin, overprinted with dragon robe motif, similarly printed sleeveless overrobe. Also included is a black satin headband with gold filigree buttons (some have been lost over the years) and a string of glass beads and polished stones that hang down the chest, and a cream quilted cotton under robe.
It comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.
description_for_label: Colour had arrived in cinema when The Last Emperor (1987) was released but its use in costume and cinematography was Oscar-winning. The film follows Pu Yi’s transition from the last emperor of China to ordinary citizen and colour is fundamental to his journey. Deep crimson and orange hues capture both the majesty and innocence of his childhood in the Forbidden City, while grey saturates moments in jail later in life. This costume by James Acheson enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, further reinforced by 9,500 extras that appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
results.credit_line_for_label:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric

results.creator_credit: GO! Media Holdings Ltd and Laser Beam (Beam Software)

results.brief_description: Bedlam [computer game]. Bedlam is a top down vertical shooting scroller in a futuristic sci fi setting for one or two players simultaneously. Players pilot a vehicle shooting and dodging aliens and fighting boss ships.

results.title: Play It Again I: Games Collection
results.brief_description:
The Play It Again I project aimed to create a playable history of Australasian video games for industry, community and research purposes, by building on existing research into the history of Beam Software and their games from the 1980s.

This collection comprises physical games donated to ACMI for the project, audio captures and game emulation files - some created at ACMI as part of the project research and some harvested from external web repositories.

The multi-faceted project brought multidisciplinary expertise to bear on the areas of collections, preservation, accessibility, fan knowledge, and the telling of histories about Australia’s digital game history.

The project was undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Flinders University, University of Melbourne, The New Zealand Film Archive, Berlin Computerspiele Museum, and the Research Trust of Victoria University of Wellington. It was funded via the Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Projects scheme, which funds collaborative projects between University researchers and Partner Organisations.

The project was completed in 2015.

description_for_label:
The Play It Again I project aimed to create a playable history of Australasian video games for industry, community and research purposes, by building on existing research into the history of Beam Software and their games from the 1980s.

This collection comprises physical games donated to ACMI for the project, audio captures and game emulation files - some created at ACMI as part of the project research and some harvested from external web repositories.

The multi-faceted project brought multidisciplinary expertise to bear on the areas of collections, preservation, accessibility, fan knowledge, and the telling of histories about Australia’s digital game history.

The project was undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Flinders University, University of Melbourne, The New Zealand Film Archive, Berlin Computerspiele Museum, and the Research Trust of Victoria University of Wellington. It was funded via the Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Projects scheme, which funds collaborative projects between University researchers and Partner Organisations.

The project was completed in 2015.
